Sri Lanka pivots from stabilisation to growth, but credibility now matters as much as momentum.

A year after averting defaultâ€™s aftershocks, Sri Lanka is trying to move from IMF-led stabilisation to investment-led expansion. Markets have noticed: the CSEâ€™s ASPI hit a record 23,000 and corporates posted muscular results (John Keellsâ€™ Q2 EBITDA up 127% to Rs. 18.36bn; NDBâ€™s 9M pre-tax profit up 62%; HNB Assurance Life GWP up 38%). Foreign-facing firms are leaning in: Colombo Dockyard signed its largest-ever order to build two cable ships for Orange Marine; Rakuten Symphony and SLT-Mobitel will run one of South Asiaâ€™s first Open RAN trials; M&A continues (SolarIT acquiring Tetris; JAT Exports buying Mirotone NZ for A$ 4m). Yet none of this will carry far if institutions stumble. Allegations around the release of â€œ309 containersâ€ at Customs, police procurement leaks and politicised extensions jar with the Governmentâ€™s reform message. Investor confidence is rising; policy credibility must keep pace.

The Budget should lock in certainty on tax and tilt policy from collection to compliance, affordability and growth.

With the 2026 Budget upon us, the market wants fewer surprises and steadier signals: maintain fiscal consolidation but reduce the cost of doing business, deepen listings (including SOEs), and ease foreign re-entry. On taxes, several voices urge pragmatism: introduce credits for firms that digitise (eâ€‘invoicing, ERP, cyberâ€‘security), a simplified presumptive regime for the service gig economy (3â€“5% on gross receipts) and a realâ€‘time taxpayer dashboard to cut friction. Others caution that tax morale depends on fairness: keep rates and thresholds steady while using data to widen the net and improve enforcementâ€”without tipping willing payers into nonâ€‘compliance. The lesson, as one analyst put it, is simple: growth needs macro prudence, but prosperity needs micro predictability.

The Government has launched a highâ€‘profile drug offensiveâ€”nearly 1,000 arrests in a day, deep-sea seizures (â‰ˆRs. 5 bn worth), and a new operations centre to fuse police, military, Customs and immigration. The hotline (1995/1818) and a turn to voluntary treatment are signs of a broader intent: from fear to prevention. The risk is familiar: dragnet arrests that clog courts and prisons, while upstream networks adapt. Sustainable progress needs measurable targetsâ€”kingpin convictions, asset forfeiture, fewer youth initiationsâ€”and insulation from politicisation. The state must also fix what it demands of citizens: due process, clean procurement, and no impunity for collusion.

The Northern economy is back on the policy map; turning potential into exports demands ports, power and people.

A drumbeat of analysis and advocacy (thinkâ€‘tank papers, business forums and an announced Northern Summit in January) frames the North and East as Sri Lankaâ€™s â€œNorthern Gatewayâ€â€”close to Indian markets, rich in fisheries and agriculture, with ports (KKS, Point Pedro) and the Palaly airport as anchors. Private and diaspora capital are awakening; public policy should follow with hard infrastructure (cold chains, lastâ€‘mile logistics, grid capacity), streamlined land use and crossâ€‘border services. The blue economy is the obvious fulcrum; governance (traceability, IUU control) is the hinge.

Tourismâ€™s recovery is labourâ€‘constrained; fix skills, not just visas.

NHRDCâ€™s new data are stark: hotels face shortages in kitchens (35%), F&B (22.8%), and housekeeping (16.6%); women are just 24% of the workforce; over 60% of exits (2020â€“23) were to overseas jobs. Training pipelines are skewed (3,000+ in cookery vs. <200 in guest relations) and curricula behind the curve (multilingual skills, digital hospitality). Retention will demand structured apprenticeships, flexible shifts, safer workplaces and career laddersâ€”especially for women. If Sri Lanka wants higherâ€‘yield visitors, it must first invest in higherâ€‘skill service.

Climate and circularity inch from CSR to core, but policy coherence lags.

Corporate moves are getting bolder: Allianz Lanka tethers policy sales to ecosystem restoration (PLANT), Bureau Veritas wins Gold for environmental performance, and GP Labs opens the countryâ€™s first dedicated plastics testing facility to validate recycled materials to ASTM/ISO standards. Yet public policy sends mixed signals. The bag levy (Rs. 3â€“5) may curb demand, but without ringâ€‘fenced revenues for collection and recycling infrastructure it risks being a regressive fee. Likewise, a proposed Hambantota refinery raises unresolved EIA, coastal and biodiversity risks. â€œEcoâ€ should be engineered as a systemâ€”products, recovery, dataâ€”not just priced at the checkout.

Foreign policy is pragmatic and plural; it should be married to trade facilitation and investment execution.

Sri Lankaâ€™s external calendar is busy and balanced: Korea marked 48 years of ties (diaspora, KOICA, EPS labour); Archbishop Gallagherâ€™s visit celebrated 50 years with the Holy See; Tokyo and Seoul welcomed new envoys; Bangladesh FOC and the UAE Joint Commission relaunched after long lulls; the Sri Lankaâ€“Thailand Business Council renewed its agenda as both sides work an FTA. These are good optics. The test is throughput: concluding legal instruments, accelerating approvals, and deâ€‘risking projects with transparent PPP frameworks. Diplomacy feeds pipelines; domestic capacity must close.

Telecoms, shipbuilding and open standards hint at a productivity turnâ€”if the digital divide is addressed.

That will need public rails (payments, identity, data protection), skilling and lastâ€‘mile accessâ€”plus a regulatory posture that promotes competition without deterring capital.

The capital market is doing its job; policymakers must avoid crowding it out.

A record market, oversubscribed IPOs (e.g., JF Packaging), and strong bank fee growth point to risk appetite returning as rates ease. Pension funds will need clear, rulesâ€‘based room to allocate to equity; foreign investors, clean exits and credible macro anchors.

Governance will decide whether reform compounds or unravels.

The simplest growth policy remains the hardest: enforce rules without fear or favour, publish the findings, and show that the â€œnewâ€ state is smaller where it should beâ€”and stronger where it must be.

Sri Lanka doubles down on green infrastructure and regional positioning even as governance creaks under reform load.

Colombo opened the LEED Goldâ€“designed SACEP headquarters, built with World Bank support under the PLEASE (Plastic Free Rivers and Seas for South Asia) program, anchoring a bid to be South Asiaâ€™s environmental hub. Port City Colombo was named fDi Intelligenceâ€™s â€œBest Knowledge Zone â€“ Asia Pacific,â€ citing its SEZ (Special Economic Zone) framework and dispute-resolution architecture. Grid reliability got a lift with Siemens and DIMO completing the countryâ€™s largest substation at Habarana, while Panasian Power tied in another 5 MW solar plant in Ampara. Yet electricity unbundling is mired in dispute: CEB engineers warned Parliament that the Preliminary Transfer Plan breaches the Sri Lanka Electricity Acts (No. 36 of 2024; No. 14 of 2025) and bypasses stakeholder consultation. â™»ï¸âš¡

A digital pivot gathers pace as state and private actors seed capacity and jobs.

The state convened AI workshops for public officers in the South and staged a national AI expo with 12,000+ visitors, while Virtusa and UK insurer CFC launched a 200-seat Colombo digital services hub. Startups secured a combined $160,000 at the â€œFirst Capital Startup Nation by Hatchâ€ demo day, and Deutsche Bank marked 45 years in Sri Lanka with fresh custody accolades. Meanwhile, the Government re-gazetted institutional portfoliosâ€”moving the Civil Security Department to Public Security and clustering digital bodies (including the Online Safety Commission) under the Digital Economy Ministryâ€”aimed at execution clarity.

Education reforms meet capacity deficits, prompting a reset toward execution and equity.

The President asked FUTA (Federation of University Teachersâ€™ Associations) for a plan to cut degree delays and strengthen research, as Parliament heard that teacher vacancies exceed 36,000 (with the Eastern and Central Provinces the most affected). Cabinet approved Rs. 761.29 million to print 6.04 million textbooks for 2026 and Rs. 630.2 million to locally manufacture assistive devices under the 2025â€“27 budget framework. A Delhi research lab was named after PM Harini Amarasuriya during her official visit, underscoring an India-facing academic bridge, while the Government faces blowbackâ€”and legal supportâ€”from the HRCSL over a proposed ban on corporal punishment (the Commission calls it international best practice).

Fiscal debates converge on credibility: consolidation must meet growth.

A raft of budget commentaries urged broadening VAT, replacing para-tariffs, and shifting from transaction taxes toward growth-friendly progressivity, warning against high cigarette smuggling (state loses ~Rs. 80 billion annually) and ad hoc incentives. Analysts flagged debt-service pressure above 40% of revenue by 2028 and stressed capital-spend quality over quantity, with the IMF program requiring a 2.3% primary surplus. The Cabinet signaled more funding in 2026 to mitigate floods, while Parliamentâ€™s oversight committee began tracking ministry-level 2025 budget executionâ€”an accountability move that still needs transparent quarterly KPIs.

Rule of law versus rule by law is in focus as the state pursues order without chilling initiative.

Legal scholars cautioned that over-reliance on â€œrule by lawâ€ (control via punitive compliance) risks a risk-averse bureaucracy; they urged measurable accountability (not simply reduced discretion) to protect service delivery. Meanwhile, a public tussle over a policeâ€“lawyer confrontation prompted calls for restraint from a former SSP, and editorial scrutiny slammed â€œsuspect pageantryâ€ during high-profile deportations. The murder of Weligamaâ€™s PS Chairman underscored persistent gun violence, even as CID probes celebrity ties to alleged underworld figures dominated headlines.

Reconciliation inches forward with land releases and historic reparations claims, but Geneva remains a test of delivery.

The Government released ~706 acres in the North and East to the public so far this year, and survivors filed a $15 million reparations claim for the 1989 Valvettithurai massacre by the IPKF (Indian Peace Keeping Force) at the Office for Reparationsâ€”a first-of-its-kind mass atrocity claim. The Government avoided a vote on the latest UNHRC resolution, but Foreign Ministry briefings show it rejecting the text while promising domestic action; policy analysts say credible progressâ€”on land, graves, prosecutions, and provincial pollsâ€”is vital to unwind external scrutiny.

The green turn is real, but project governance must respect ecosystems and law.

Mannarâ€™s wind rollout faces allegations of Ramsar and wildlife law breaches by activists, who cite bird and turtle impacts and flooding from blocked canals; they urge a moratorium pending proper EIAs and community consent. In the hills, repeated human-caused fires ravaged the 38.6 kmÂ² Hanthana EPA (Environmental Protection Area), exposing weak enforcement and the difficulty of prosecuting arson under the Forest Act. Conservationists, meanwhile, celebrated the Tea Boardâ€™s GI (Geographical Indication) projectâ€”Ceylon Teaâ€™s EU registration would protect origin and valueâ€”while Dutch Trails and Aitken Spence were honored for sustainability programs. ğŸŒ¿

Social fabric strains are visibleâ€”from microfinance debt to cyber harmsâ€”requiring targeted, data-led response.

A feminist coalition warned the new Microfinance Bill could â€œtighten the nooseâ€ on women debtors unless predatory lending and interest caps are addressed, and called for a national debt database. The 2025 Sri Lanka Barometer found rising civic engagement but uneven perceptions of reconciliation; an online tool now opens all four survey waves to the public. On digital harms, cyberbullying cases are up, spurring calls to pair legal enforcement with school-based digital literacy and platform accountability; media ethics were also scrutinized for sensationalism around suspects. ğŸ§©

Tourism, trade and aviation push outwardâ€”while South Asiaâ€™s trade shock demands pragmatism.

Sri Lanka courted Italians at TTG Rimini (Italian arrivals up 33% y/y in Janâ€“Sep), Emirates launched a technician-recruitment roadshow in Colombo, and the SLâ€“Greater Mekong council sought tighter links with ASEAN supply chains. A regional economist roundtable urged South Asia to â€œpivot to Asiaâ€ and decouple trade from geopolitics, as US tariff volatility pushed the World Uncertainty Index up fivefold (Aug 2024â€“Aug 2025); they called for domestic reforms, regional trade pragmatism, and WTO strengthening.

Markets prize strong governance signals: engineering ratings, board changes and capital market depth.

Fitch assigned Hayleys Fentons an inaugural A+(lka), while appointments at the CSE, Lanka Ventures/LVL Energy, Lanka Realty, and others point to governance renewal. The CSE saw robust turnover (Rs. 9â€“12 billion range on strong days) and crossings in banking, energy, and consumer counters, though profit-taking tempered rallies. Waste-to-energy facilities co-processed ~9,000 kg of illicit cigarettes (two consignments worth ~Rs. 1.1 billion), feeding clean power to the gridâ€”a small but symbolic blending of rule-of-law and circular economy. âš–ï¸ğŸ”„

The stateâ€™s agenda is crowded; sequencing and trust will decide outcomes.

From education bottlenecks to energy market restructuring, from flood-proofing cities to securing GI labels for export brands, the Government is advancing on many fronts. The risk is overreach without consultation: PC (Provincial Council) polls remain in limbo, key reforms lack public debate, and legal moves (e.g., child-protection amendments) have run into stakeholder resistance. The weekâ€™s throughline is clear: execution, consultation, and evidenceâ€”not mandates aloneâ€”will determine whether targets become results.

A government promising system change faces old-system tests in law, policing and devolution.

One year into President Anura Kumara Dissanayakeâ€™s administration, Sri Lankaâ€™s institutions are stress-tested by familiar frictions. The Cabinet signalled elections to long-dormant Provincial Councils in 2026 (if necessary under the â€œold systemâ€), as debate sharpened over devolution tied to the UNHRCâ€™s latest resolution on Sri Lanka. Meanwhile, policing came under scrutiny on two fronts: the CID disclosed a caseload of â€œover 20,000 ongoing or pending investigationsâ€ (context: national backlogs), and a Mount Lavinia courthouse confrontation between a lawyer and a police constable prompted duelling allegations and raised questions about independence and restraint within justice institutions. A UN technical mission also sounded out party leaders on electoral-system support, emphasising inclusion, transparency and digitalisation.

Anti-corruption goes digital as the bribery commission rolls out case tracking, but beneficial ownership compliance will be the next grind.

The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption launched a digital Case-File Tracking System with UNDP/Japan support to standardise workflows and statisticsâ€”an IMF governance benchmark. In parallel, the Registrar of Companies confirmed roll-out of the Companies (Amendment) Act, No. 12 of 2025: firms must identify and maintain registers of beneficial owners and file seven BO forms; non-compliance carries fines (up to 4% of EU-wide turnover in the EUDR context; domestic penalties vary) and potential criminal liability. Regulators acknowledged real enforcement hurdlesâ€”layered corporate structures, offshore entities and limited dataâ€”suggesting a long compliance runway, not a sprint.

Customs revenue peaks while policy inconsistency remains a risk signal for investors.

Sri Lanka Customs recorded its highest-ever single-day revenue at Rs. 24.9 billion (15 Oct), with Rs. 1.86 trillion year-to-date (target: Rs. 2.11 trillion) as vehicle imports resume. Yet legal disputes persistâ€”on container releases earlier this year and LC anomalies on vehicle importsâ€”underscoring the need for rule clarity. The BOI courted a 23-member US think-tank delegation, pitching macro-stability, logistics and zone reforms; but two sober policy op-eds argued that investor confidence still hinges on fixing six structural bottlenecksâ€”high/hidden trade barriers, customs lag, tax unpredictability, rigid labour laws and politicised bureaucracyâ€”rather than incentives alone.

Colomboâ€™s maritime machine hums louder, aided by new capacity.

The SLPA reported a profit of Rs. 32.2 billion for Janâ€“Aug 2025 (up 71% year-on-year; target was ~Rs. 21 billion) and expects the Port of Colombo to handle a record 8.2 million TEUs in 2025 (vs. 7.78 million in 2024), helped by ramp-up at the West Container Terminal and transhipment diverted from the Red Sea (context: rerouting via Cape of Good Hope). Capacity is slated to double to 15 million TEUs by 2026. Policy-wise, Cabinet greenlit Rs. 1.3 billion for an Excise revenue system and Rs. 1.45 billion to modernise Kolonnawa filling facilitiesâ€”incremental digitisation to tighten leakages.

Capital markets rally as crossings surge and sector earnings broaden.

Turnover exceeded Rs. 8 billion on multiple sessions; crossings spanned blue chips (DFCC, ComBank, HNB, JKH) and mid-caps (Hemas, CDB, LB Finance), reflecting deepening liquidity. The All Share dipped midweek on profit-taking, though banking, finance and manufacturing led activity; rupee hovered around Rs. 302.6â€“303.0/USD. IPO pipelines ticked up (JF Packaging), while energy transition plays advancedâ€”WindForce acquired 51% of a 10 MW Alankuda wind project (total cost Rs. 4.2 billion, 75:25 debt/equity). CEB unions suspended a strike after the minister accepted 24 proposalsâ€”signalling a fragile truce in the power sector âš¡.

The Port City legal reset seeks predictability after incentives were repealed.

Cabinet instructed the Legal Draftsman to amend the Colombo Port City Economic Commission Act (No. 11 of 2021), following repeal of strategic-business regulations on 4 Aug (those rules had codified incentives/exemptions). The aim: restore competitive certainty, align with national law and investor protections, and clarify inter-agency roles. Separately, new amendments to the Companies Act on beneficial ownership (see above) will shape KYC (know-your-customer) across Port City dealings.

Wages and prices move: a higher minimum and selective rice imports.

The minimum monthly wage for private-sector workers rises to Rs. 27,000 from 1 April 2025 (and to Rs. 30,000 from 1 Jan 2026), with EPF/ETF and statutory payments indexedâ€”narrowing real-wage compression. To ease a Keeri Samba shortage, Cabinet allowed import of up to 520 MT of GR-11/Ponni Samba per importer without permits (15 Octâ€“15 Nov)â€”a targeted intervention (annual rice consumption ~2.46 million MT, Keeri share ~10%). Gold surged to records (22k at Rs. 337,600, 24k at Rs. 365,000 per sovereign), tracking global moves and domestic hedging.

Health policy balanced expansion in supply with watchdog alarm on hospital stocks.

The Health Ministry approved ~Rs. 2.5 billion in procurements (epoetin for CKD patients; infliximab; antibiotics; consumables) via international bids and appeal-board vetting. Doctorsâ€™ unions warned of simultaneous oversupply of ~100 drug lines and acute shortages in essential medicines (e.g., noradrenaline, cefotaxime) and surgical items, citing fragmented procurement and regional purchases that risk leakages. On infrastructure, Rs. 5.9 million for a CIDA roof repair drew COPEâ€™s ire over process and legality (legal costs in a staff case: ~Rs. 15 million). Regionally, the WHO SEARO adopted the Colombo Declaration on healthy ageing, with Sri Lanka chairing the session and highlighting demographic pressures (1 in 4 Sri Lankans â‰¥65 by 2045).

Environmental policy is being shaped by Brussels as much as by Colombo.

Two separate analyses of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) warned exportersâ€”especially in rubber and rubber-based productsâ€”to prepare for geolocation, due diligence statements, and lawful-origin proofs by Dec 2025 (SMEs: Jun 2026). The apparel sector showcased tangible progressâ€”net-zero facilities, 39% renewables at MAS, 99% landfill diversionâ€”with UNGC engagement on circular supply chains. Locally, conservationists urged Sri Lanka Cricket to rethink a 52-acre stadium plan at Mandaitivu (Jaffna), citing â€œblue carbonâ€ mangroveâ€“seagrassâ€“saltmarsh ecosystems, flood and storm surge risks, and spatial plans marking it a high-sensitivity zone ğŸŒŠ.

Digital governance and public services had both outage warning lights and reform green shoots.

A Lanka Government Cloud (LGC) outage temporarily disrupted digital services (BMD certificates, e-revenue licenses, police clearance). ICTA said capacity relief is due from a new LGC expansion phase started in Oct 2025. Separately, the Government will sign AML/CFT MoUs with the Vatican and Mauritius (FIUs), aligning supervision ahead of FATF scrutiny. The Cabinet approved the â€˜Ratama Ekataâ€™ inter-agency anti-drug operation with community engagementâ€”after the Navy seized ~839 kg of narcotics (ice, heroin, hashish) drifting off the south coast.

Growth hopes rest on logistics, rare minerals and re-mobilising tourismâ€”if the rules are credible.

A research-led tourism forum argued for a pivot to higher-yield segments and stronger governance. The port/aviation build-out (Central Expressway resumption under BRI; airport runway tender retrospectives) underlines the necessity of transparent, competitive procurement. In minerals, commentators pressed for a rare earths and graphite value-add strategy, tied to updated surveys, environmental responsibility and geopolitically balanced partnershipsâ€”avoiding the curse of exporting raw sands while importing dependency.

The social ledger: ageing, education, mental healthâ€”and air we breathe.

Education debates widenedâ€”from context-sensitive reforms in rural districts to duty-of-care for special needs and teacher deployment.
